Julia Hurst , executive director with the National Lieutenant Governors Association , said lieutenant governors become governor at a greater rate than any other type of elected official â 1 in 4 nationwide from 1980 through 2006 .
âNo other office is more of a springboard office than the office of lieutenant governor , â she said .
In Pennsylvania , only four men became governor since 1900 â all Republicans â after serving as lieutenant governor .
Raymond Shafer was elected in 1967 after serving as lieutenant governor under Gov. Bill Scranton .
Arthur James ascended to the higher office in 1939 .
Mark Schweiker ascended to the job when Gov. Tom Ridge resigned to become the first Secretary of the federal Department of Homeland Security .
He did not seek election .
Lt. Gov. John C. Bell became the state 's shortest - serving governor for 19 days in 1947 , when Gov. Edward Martin resigned his term to serve in the U.S. Senate .
